p: In total, 41% (48/118) of PSE were referenced to identify a problem. The most common of such problems were gaps in response and/or service coverage, and to highlight the lack of comprehensive data on the target population. FSW were the most frequently mentioned population (38%), with PWID being the least mentioned (27%). Of the PSE used to identify a problem, 29% (14/48) were used to develop a plan of action or develop a recommendation to address the problem for 9 countries, including Angola, Cameroon, Egypt, Kenya, Morocco, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, and South Africa. Five of the countries referenced one key population in the plans of actions and recommendations, with Niger [ 62] and Nigeria [ 63] referencing PSE for FSW; Senegal referencing PSE for PWID [ 57]; Ghana referencing a national PSE estimate for FSW [ 61]; and Angola referencing PSE for MSM [ 55]. Three of the countries referenced PSE for two key populations including: South Africa referencing FSW and PWID [ 59]; Morocco referencing PSE for MSM and PWID [ 64]; and Kenya referencing PSE for FSW and PWID [ 60]. One country, Egypt, referenced PSE for 3 key populations: FSW, MSM, and PWID [ 65]. In all references used to develop a plan of action, resources proposed were directed towards rather than away from key populations.
